content:
Ecomechanics
Ecomechanics is a biomechanic scientific discipline studying the mechanisms underlying organisms' interactions with their environment. It incorporates elements of ecology and comparative physiology, as an outgrowth of biomechanics.{"citetype": "journal", "date": "2009-07-21", "title": "Confronting the physiological bottleneck: A challenge from ecomechanics", "url": "http://icb.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/content/full/49/3/197", "journal": "Integrative and Comparative Biology Advance Access 2009 49: 197-201", "volume": "49", "issue": "3", "pages": "197\u2013201", "doi": "10.1093/icb/icp070", "pmid": "20607137", "author": "[[Mark Denny]]", "author2": "Brian Helmuth"} The term was originally coined by Dr. M. A. R. Koehl[citation needed]. The field gained its own recognition as the result of a working group at Friday Harbor Laboratories on September 2009[citation needed].
